Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to develop scattering, imaging, and digital image analysis tools, combined with deformable tissue culture scaffolds, to investigate the mechanics of angiogenesis in 3D systems. Angiogenesis is formation of blood vessels within developing and wounded tissue, an essential process for oxygen, nutrient, and waste exchange between blood and metabolically active cells. Studies conducted under this award will apply dynamic light and x-ray scattering, and time-lapse imaging, to measure morphology, motion, and force generation in endothelial cell networks growing within 3D scaffolds. Culture scaffold material properties and chemical functionality the will be investigated to determine their role in angiogenesis. In parallel, molecular biology techniques will be employed to study the underlying molecular mechanisms of angiogenesis, including genetic screens, histological evaluation of cell networks, and immunohistochemical evaluations of angiogenic marker expression.

If successful, these studies would add significantly to the field?s understanding of mechanics in angiogenesis and represent an integration of time-lapse characterization tools, scaffold engineering, and molecular biology for 3D cell mechanics studies. The knowledge gained from these efforts will enhance the field?s ability to investigate collective cell mechanics in other 3D tissue constructs, providing a set of tools for the large multicellular systems typically found in tissue engineering, wound healing, and regenerative medicine studies, and advancing technology development within these areas. The educational plan focuses on digital imaging and analysis tools for use in K-12 science classes, and the creation of an annual workshop with educators at a partner school in which teaching modules will be developed and distributed to participating science teachers. The initiative will involve extensive sharing of analysis software and discussions of how to effectively incorporate contemporary imaging and analysis tools to improve the communication of scientific concepts that are difficult to grasp, or difficult to observe, without these tools.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this project, the investigators discovered a new class of physical interactions that occur between cells. Previously, cells were thought to physically interact only through elastic forces. The investigators discovered that cells also exert forces on one another through the fluids that they drive back and forth into one another. These newly discovered fluid forces were shown to tightly couple to multicellular behavior; when groups of cells in a continuum contract, neighboring groups expand, taking in fluid from the contracting cells. The investigators showed that this fluid flow could be used to infer a map of pressure generated throughout a continuum of cells, creating a totally new tool for measuring cellular mechanical acitivity. Another major discovery was made under this project: cell generated tensile forces can drive mechanical instabilities from within multi-cellular structures. This mechanism for determining meso-scale morphology informs our undersanding of processes in developmental biology, wound healing, and diseased tissue. These discoveries represent new fundamental knowledge in biophysics, cell mechanics, cell biology with implications in tissue engineering and medicine. The extremely basic level of these new views on cell mechanics give them a broad reach into these many areas, providing the potential to transform our broad understanding of multicellular physics. 

Throughout this project, students at many different stages of education were exposed to science, technology, engineering and mathematics. One student earned a PhD in Mechanical engineering (Steven M. Zehnder); one student earned a Master's degree; several undergraduate students received research experience; k-12 students participated in lab activities, studying soft matter physics and biophysics. Students from groups underrepresented in the STEM fields were provided with research experience and educational opportunities. Several female, hispanic, and african american undraduate college students participated in reserach or co-authored peer-reviewed manuscripts that are now published (Melanie Suaris, Madisonclaire Bellaire, Marina Kay Wiatt, Federico Zegers, Andy Nelson, Carmen Gil). These publications are a very clear positive outcome of the project. The k-12 students who performed lab activities with the PI were all female, coming from an afterschool activity center (Girlsplace, Gainesville, FL).  Another excellent outcome of the project is that the female Masters of Science student (Jolie Frketic) is now pursuing a PhD.


Last Modified: 03/03/2016
Modified by: Thomas Angelini

Images (1 of )
  • Each MDCK cell in the small group is tagged with its own color to aid in following size changes over time (B). Data analysis shows that cells fluctuate in volume by about +/- 20% about their mean (C). Autocorrelation analysis reveals an oscillation time of about 4 hours (D).
    Thomas Angelini
